title: 110_hr6020
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lance Corporal Jose Gutierrez Act of 2008" and facilitates naturalization for military personnel. The "Lance Corporal Jose Gutierrez Act of 2008" allows military personnel who served honorably in support of contingency operations to be eligible for naturalization under specific provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act. This includes amending the required service period for naturalization through service in the Armed Forces of the United States. The "Facilitating Removal of Conditional Status for Military Personnel and Their Families" section aims to streamline the process for military personnel and their families to obtain permanent residency. The amendment allows military personnel to file petitions for permanent residency within 6 months of discharge. Amendment allows military personnel to file petitions for permanent residency within 6 months of discharge, with the requirement of timely petition and interview for removal of condition. Factors to consider when initiating removal proceedings against active duty military personnel or veterans are outlined in Section 4. Section 239 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to exempt honorably discharged veterans from receiving a notice to appear for deportation without approval from USCIS or ICE. Factors considered include eligibility for naturalization, military service record, deportability grounds, and potential hardship to the individual and their family. An alien who served honorably in the Armed Forces of the United States shall not be removed from the United States under certain circumstances. Active duty military personnel, veterans, and their family members may be eligible for discretionary relief in removal proceedings. Aliens who served honorably in the Armed Forces of the United States, or are family members of military personnel, may be exempt from certain grounds of inadmissibility under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Aliens may be exempt from certain grounds of inadmissibility under the Immigration and Nationality Act if they meet specific criteria related to their incarceration or convictions. The court may waive provisions for aliens who did not reasonably believe they were citizens at the time of violation. Factors considered for waiver include grounds of inadmissibility, military service, impact on family members in the Armed Forces, and length of time lived in the US. The factors considered for waiver of provisions for aliens include the impact on family ties in the United States, employment history, ties to the country, and the degree of adverse effects on family members or employers. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act exempts military service personnel and their family members from certain grounds of deportability, including those who served honorably in the Armed Forces of the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security or the Attorney General cannot waive certain subsections related to aggravated felonies under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security or the Attorney General cannot waive certain subsections related to aggravated felonies under the Immigration and Nationality Act, including offenses specified in subsections (a)(2)(A), (a)(2)(D)(i) or (ii), (a)(2)(D)(iii) for violations of the Trading With the Enemy Act, (a)(2)(D)(iv) for violations of section 278, (a)(4)(A), (B), (C)(i), (D), or (E), and (a)(6)(A) for certain convictions, awards, compromises, settlements, or injunctions. The Secretary of Homeland Security or the Attorney General may waive certain provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act for aliens who did not reasonably believe they were citizens at the time of violation. Factors considered for waiver include grounds of deportability, military service, impact on family members in the Armed Forces, and length of time lived in the US. The factors considered for waiver of certain provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act for aliens include the impact on family ties in the United States, employment history, ties to employers or businesses, and the degree of impact on family members. The factors considered for waiver of certain provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act for aliens include ties to the community in the United States or contributions to the Nation through community, volunteer, or other activities. SEC. 6 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to allow timely reunification of military personnel with their nuclear families. SEC. 7 provides relief for immediate family members of active duty personnel. The Secretary of Homeland Security can adjust the status of eligible aliens to lawful permanent residents if they meet certain criteria, including being physically present in the US when applying, being admissible as an immigrant, and paying a processing fee. Eligible aliens include family members of Armed Forces members. Eligible members of the Armed Forces, including those in the Selected Reserve or active-duty status, may qualify for adjustment under this section for 2 years after the death of a service member due to service-related injury or disease. The executive order designates a period of military conflict and honorable separation from service as eligibility criteria for adjustment of status. Certain grounds of inadmissibility are waived for this purpose, except for cases involving incarceration for 5 years or more. The executive order allows for adjustment of status for individuals with military service, waiving certain grounds of inadmissibility except for cases involving incarceration for 5 years or more for specific offenses. The Secretary of Homeland Security or the Attorney General may waive other provisions of section 212(a) of the law. The executive order allows for adjustment of status for individuals with military service, waiving certain grounds of inadmissibility. The Secretary of Homeland Security or the Attorney General may waive provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act for humanitarian purposes, family unity, or public interest.
